title: Rust doesn't tRust me
body:
I'm loving what I'm learning about Rust.

I had to stop and remark about this bit of code that I encountered early in my journey learning this language. This is an very safe language.

Straight out of Steve Donovan's "A gentle Introduction to Rust" we hit a 'feature' of the compiler that put a smile on my face.

We start with the problem:

"Write a program that sums up the first 5 integers and display the results"

Sounds simple enough.

In Rust, he proposes this simple solution:

fn main() {
    let sum = 0;
    for i in 0..5 {
        sum += i;
    }
    println!("sum is {}", sum);
}

The magic is in the compile ERROR (not a warning, and actual STOP IT, I REFUSE TO RUN THIS!)

error[E0384]: re-assignment of immutable variable `sum`

What? immutable?

immutable: unchanging over time or unable to be changed.

So, it looks like, by default, when you define a 'variable' - it's not variable!

you are not allowed to change the value of a variable unless you explicitly tell the compiler that it's 'changeable' or in programmer language 'mutable'

let mut sum = 0;

I don't belive I have ever come across a language that assumes immutable objects by default, but I see where we are going here.

Programmers are not to be trusted. And I've been writing code for so long, that I know I can't trust myself either.

Rust doesn't tRust me. I like this.

title: The Inception
body:
Welcome to 'The Journey'. This is a space where I will be documenting thoughts, technical challenges, and the evolution of OpenForge Solutions.

Today, we are starting simple: a JSON-backed content system that separates data from presentation, allowing us to focus on writing without the immediate overhead of a database.

The beautiful thing is that I shamelessly used Gemini to write the basics of this system, because getting something into production fast - even if it's a little flawed, is so much better than spending hours on a perfect solution without delivering.

Most of the content of this website was generated with AI, especially the javascript, because writing javascript does not give me joy
